ListOfCode.Content:
terraform {
  required_providers {
    storyblok = {
      source  = "labd/storyblok"
      version = "0.0.1"
    }
  }
}

provider "storyblok" {
  url   = "https://mapi.storyblok.com"
  token = "<my-token>"
}

resource "storyblok_component" "banner" {
  name     = "my-banner" // The technical name of the component.
  space_id = "<my-space-id>" // The ID of the space.
  is_root  = true // Component should be usable as a Content Type
  is_nestable = true // Component should be insertable in blocks field type fields
  component_group_uuid = "<uuid-of-the-component-group>" // The UUID of the component group.

  schema = {
    title = {
      type     = "text" // The type of the field
      position = 1 // The position of the field
      add_https = true // Prepends https: to stop usage of relative protocol
      asset_folder_id = 123 // Default asset folder numeric id to store uploaded image of that field
      can_sync = true // Advanced usage to sync with field in preview; Default: false
      component_whitelist = ["post", "page", "product"] // Array of component/content type names: ["post","page","product"]
      datasource_slug = "internal" // Define selectable datasources string; Effects editor only if source=internal
      default_value = "Default text" // Default value for the field; Can be an escaped JSON object
      description = "This is a title field." // Description shown in the editor interface
      disable_time = false // Disables time selection from date picker; Default: false
      display_name = "Title" // Display name shown in the editor interface
      external_datasource = "https://api.example.com/data" // Define external datasource JSON Url; Effects editor only if source=external
      field_type = "custom" // Name of the custom field type plugin
      filetypes = ["images", "videos", "audios", "texts"] // Array of file type names: ["images", "videos", "audios", "texts"]
      folder_slug = "{0}/categories/" // Filter on selectable stories path; Effects editor only if source=internal_stories; In case you have a multi-language folder structure you can add the '{0}' placeholder and the path will be adapted dynamically. Examples: "{0}/categories/", {0}/{1}/categories/
      image_crop = false // Activate force crop for images: (true/false)
      image_height = "300px" // Define height in px or height ratio if keep_image_size is enabled
      image_width = "200px" // Define width in px or width ratio if keep_image_size is enabled
      keep_image_size = true // Keep original size: (true/false)
      keys = ["key1", "key2"] // Array of field keys to include in this section
      max_length = 100 // Set the max length of the input string
      maximum = 10 // Maximum amount of added bloks in this blok field
      no_translate = false // Should be excluded in translation export
      options = { option1 = "Option 1", option2 = "Option 2" } // Array of datasource entries [{name:"", value:""}]; Effects editor only if source=undefined
      preview_field = true // Is used as instance preview field below component name in bloks types
      regex = "^\\d+$" // Client Regex validation for the field
      required = true // Is field required; Default: false
      restrict_components = false // Activate restriction nestable component option; Default: false
      restrict_content_types = false // Activate restriction content type option
      rich_markdown = true // Enable rich markdown view by default (true/false)
      rtl = false // Enable global RTL for this field
      source = "internal_stories" // Possible values: undefined: Self; internal_stories: Stories; internal: Datasource; external: API Endpoint in Datasource Entries Array Format
      tooltip = true // Show the description as a tooltip
      translatable = false // Can field be translated; Default: false
      use_uuid = true // Default: true; available in option and source=internal_stories
    }
  }
}

https://chat.openai.com/share/f2b7484c-8.Prompt: Please can you tell me how to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the Spring repository? So not a database exception but something else after the repository has invoked and completed a save operation?
https://chat.openai.com/share/f2b7484c-8.Answer: In Spring, the process of rolling back a transaction when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository involves using transaction management and the appropriate configuration. By default, Spring uses declarative transaction management, which allows you to define transaction boundaries declaratively using annotations or XML configuration.Here's an approach you can follow to roll back a Spring repository save when an exception is thrown outside of the repository:Enable transaction management: Ensure that transaction management is enabled in your Spring application. This can be done by configuring the appropriate transaction manager bean, such as DataSourceTransactionManager for database transactions.Define transaction boundaries: Specify the boundaries of your transaction by annotating the service method that calls the repository save operation with the @Transactional annotation. This annotation can be applied to class-level or method-level, depending on your requirements.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Handle exceptions: Make sure to catch any exceptions that occur outside of the repository, either in your service layer or any higher layer. In the catch block, you can either log the exception or perform any necessary error handling.Trigger rollback: To trigger a rollback when an exception occurs, you can re-throw the caught exception or throw a new exception from your catch block. By default, Spring's transaction management will roll back the transaction when a runtime exception is thrown.For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]By following this approach, when an exception occurs outside of the Spring repository, the transaction will be marked for rollback, and any changes made during the repository save operation will be rolled back.It's worth noting that for this approach to work, you need to ensure that your Spring repository is invoked within the transactional boundaries defined by the @Transactional annotation.

https://chat.openai.com/share/b515e3dc-6.Answer: You can change the ephemeral port range and the TIME_WAIT interval settings on both Linux, macOS, and Windows. However, keep in mind that these are system-wide settings, not specific to your application, so changing these settings could potentially affect other applications running on the same system.LinuxIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeYou can view the current range with:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To increase the range, edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file and add or modify the following lines:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then apply the changes with sysctl -p.Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalYou can see the current TIME_WAIT interval with:[CODE_BLOCK_2]To reduce the TIME_WAIT interval, edit the /etc/sysctl.conf file and add or modify the following line:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Then apply the changes with sysctl -p.macOSIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeYou can increase the ephemeral port range on macOS using the sysctl command. However, macOS automatically manages the port range, so typically, you don't need to adjust this.Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalUnfortunately, macOS does not provide a way to adjust the TIME_WAIT interval.WindowsIncreasing the Ephemeral Port RangeTo see the current port range, open a command prompt and type:[CODE_BLOCK_4]To increase the range, use the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Reducing the TIME_WAIT IntervalThe TIME_WAIT interval can be adjusted through the Windows Registry. The key is HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\TcpTimedWaitDelay. This is a DWORD value that represents the time in seconds that a connection will stay in the TIME_WAIT state before being closed. The valid range is from 0x1E (30 seconds) to 0x12C (300 seconds). Note that making this interval too short could potentially cause connection issues.Again, please keep in mind that changing these settings could potentially affect other applications running on the same system, so they should be changed with caution. Also, these changes typically require administrative privileges.

https://chat.openai.com/share/db090593-4.Answer: Java의 Stream API에는 다양한 종류의 최종 연산자가 있으며, 이 중 일부는 단일 객체를 반환합니다. 일반적으로 이러한 연산자들은 컬렉션의 요소를 처리하고, 그 결과를 단일 객체로 압축합니다. 여기 몇 가지 예시를 들어 보겠습니다:reduce(): 이 연산자는 두 요소를 받아 새로운 요소를 생성하는 함수를 사용하여 스트림의 모든 요소를 단일 요소로 축소합니다. 예를 들어, 스트림의 모든 정수를 더하는 함수를 사용할 수 있습니다.[CODE_BLOCK_0]collect(): 이 연산자는 Collector 인터페이스를 구현하는 객체를 사용하여 스트림의 요소를 단일 객체로 수집합니다. 예를 들어, 스트림의 요소를 List로 수집하거나 문자열로 결합할 수 있습니다.[CODE_BLOCK_1]min(), max(): 이들 연산자는 스트림의 최솟값 또는 최댓값을 찾는 데 사용됩니다. 이 연산자들은 비교 함수를 인자로 받으며, 결과는 Optional 객체입니다.[CODE_BLOCK_2]findFirst(), findAny(): 이들 연산자는 스트림에서 첫 번째 요소 또는 어떤 요소를 찾는 데 사용됩니다. 이들은 Optional 객체를 반환합니다.[CODE_BLOCK_3]이 외에도 다른 최종 연산자들이 있습니다. 각 연산자가 반환하는 값의 유형은 해당 연산자의 동작에 따라 달라집니다. 일부 연산자는 Optional을 반환하며, 일부는 특정 유형의 객체를 반환합니다. 이는 연산이 실패하거나 결과가 없을 경우를 처리하기 위한 것입니다.

ListOfCode.Content: Optional<Integer> sum = numbers.stream().reduce(Integer::sum);

List<String> list = strings.stream().collect(Collectors.toList());

String joined = strings.stream().collect(Collectors.joining(", "));

Optional<Integer> min = numbers.stream().min(Integer::compare);
Optional<Integer> max = numbers.stream().max(Integer::compare);

Optional<String> first = strings.stream().findFirst();
Optional<String> any = strings.stream().findAny();

https://chat.openai.com/share/a91172f5-5.Prompt: GPT야 JPA를 사용할 때 DB에서 id값을 가져와야되 이럴때 entity의 생성자에서는 굳이 id에 관한 생성자를 만들어 줄 필요는 없는거야? 왜 그런거야?
https://chat.openai.com/share/a91172f5-5.Answer: 맞습니다, JPA를 사용할 때 Entity의 생성자에서 ID에 관한 생성자를 만들어 주지 않아도 됩니다. JPA에서는 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식과 객체 생성 방식 때문에 해당 생성자를 만들 필요가 없습니다.JPA에서 Entity의 ID 값을 관리하는 방식은 크게 두 가지로 나뉩니다:자동 생성 (Auto-generated ID): 일반적으로 RDBMS에서 많이 사용되는 방식으로, 데이터베이스가 Entity가 저장될 때 자동으로 ID 값을 생성해주는 방식입니다. 대표적으로 AUTO_INCREMENT와 같은 기능이 이에 해당합니다.수동 생성 (Manual ID assignment): 개발자가 직접 ID 값을 설정하는 방식입니다. 주로 외부 시스템과의 데이터 동기화 등 특수한 경우에 사용됩니다.대부분의 경우, ID 값은 데이터베이스에서 자동으로 생성되기 때문에 생성자에서 ID 값을 명시적으로 받을 필요가 없습니다. JPA는 Entity가 영속성 컨텍스트에 추가될 때 ID 값을 확인하고 적절한 방식으로 설정해주기 때문입니다.Entity 클래스는 보통 기본 생성자를 만들어주는 것이 권장됩니다. 이렇게 기본 생성자를 만들어두면 JPA가 객체를 생성하고 초기화할 때 사용하게 됩니다. 만약 개발자가 특정 생성자를 정의하고 있는데 기본 생성자가 없다면 JPA가 Entity를 올바르게 생성할 수 없을 수 있습니다.예를 들어, JPA가 기본 생성자를 찾지 못해 오류가 발생하는 상황:[CODE_BLOCK_0]이 경우, JPA는 기본 생성자를 찾을 수 없기 때문에 오류가 발생할 수 있습니다. 따라서 기본 생성자를 추가하는 것이 좋습니다:[CODE_BLOCK_1]결론적으로, JPA에서 ID 값을 가져오는 경우 Entity의 생성자에 ID에 관한 매개변수를 추가할 필요는 없습니다. JPA가 올바른 방식으로 ID 값을 설정하고 객체를 생성하도록 기본 생성자를 제공하는 것이 중요합니다.

https://chat.openai.com/share/776c0d11-1.Prompt: how can I create muliple dataframes in python from one dataframe group by a date column?
https://chat.openai.com/share/776c0d11-1.Answer: To create multiple DataFrames in Python from one DataFrame by grouping it based on a date column, you can use the groupby() function from the pandas library. Here's an example of how you can do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the groupby() function is used to group the DataFrame df by the 'date' column. The pd.Grouper() function is used to specify the frequency of grouping, in this case, 'D' for daily grouping. You can adjust the frequency based on your specific requirements, such as 'M' for monthly grouping or 'Y' for yearly grouping.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. You can perform any additional operations or analysis on each new DataFrame as needed.Note that the above example assumes you have a pandas DataFrame named 'df' with a column named 'date' containing datetime values. Adjust the code accordingly if your DataFrame or column names differ.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Assuming you have a DataFrame named 'df' with a 'date' column

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type if it's not already
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # 'group_name' is the date value
    # 'group_data' is the corresponding data for that date
    
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)

https://chat.openai.com/share/776c0d11-1.Prompt: can you show me an example of this code on a sample dataframe?
https://chat.openai.com/share/776c0d11-1.Answer: Certainly! Here's an example code snippet that demonstrates how to create multiple DataFrames from a sample DataFrame by grouping it based on a date column:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the sample DataFrame has two columns: 'date' and 'value'. The 'date' column contains date values, and the 'value' column contains some arbitrary values.The code converts the 'date' column to datetime type using pd.to_datetime() to ensure proper grouping.Then, the DataFrame is grouped by the 'date' column using groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D')), specifying daily ('D') frequency.Inside the loop, a new DataFrame named new_df is created for each group using the pd.DataFrame() constructor. In this case, it contains all the rows corresponding to each date.Finally, the code prints each new DataFrame, displaying the data grouped by date for demonstration purposes.

ListOfCode.Content:
import pandas as pd

# Sample DataFrame
data = {'date': ['2023-06-01', '2023-06-01', '2023-06-02', '2023-06-02', '2023-06-03'],
        'value': [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Convert the 'date' column to datetime type
df['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['date'])

# Group the DataFrame by the 'date' column
grouped = df.groupby(pd.Grouper(key='date', freq='D'))

# Iterate over the groups and create individual DataFrames
for group_name, group_data in grouped:
    # Create a new DataFrame for each group
    new_df = pd.DataFrame(group_data)
    
    # Perform any additional operations or analysis on the new DataFrame
    
    # Print the new DataFrame for demonstration purposes
    print(f"DataFrame for {group_name}:")
    print(new_df)
    print()

https://chat.openai.com/share/7f2d011a-a.Prompt: My codebase has a lot of old Go code which uses camel case file names like `tlsConfigHelper.go`. I'd like for all of these files to be renamed to use snake case like `tls_config_helper.go`. Can you write a bash script which will do this?
https://chat.openai.com/share/7f2d011a-a.Answer: Certainly! Here's a bash script that can help you rename the Go files from camel case to snake case:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Make sure to replace /path/to/your/codebase with the actual path to your codebase's root folder.Here's how the script works:It changes the current directory to your codebase root folder.It uses the find command to search for all Go files with camel case names.The resulting file paths are filtered using grep to exclude files that don't have a lowercase followed by an uppercase letter in their paths.For each file, it extracts the directory and base name.It converts the camel case base name to snake case using sed and tr.It constructs the new file name by appending the snake case base name to the original directory path.It renames the file using the mv command.Finally, it prints a message indicating the file has been renamed.Please be cautious when running scripts that modify your codebase, and consider making a backup or using version control before executing this script.

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/bin/bash

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
cd /path/to/your/codebase

# Find all Go files with camel case names
files=$(find . -type f -name "*.go" | grep -P '.*\/[a-z]+[A-Z]+.*')

# Loop through each file and rename it
for file in $files; do
  # Get the file's directory and base name
  dir=$(dirname "$file")
  base=$(basename "$file")

  # Convert camel case to snake case
  snake_case=$(echo "$base" | sed -E 's/([^A-Z])([A-Z])/\1_\2/g' | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]')

  # Construct the new file name
  new_name="$dir/$(dirname "$base")_$snake_case"

  # Rename the file
  mv "$file" "$new_name"

  echo "Renamed $file to $new_name"
done

import os
import re

# Change directory to your codebase root folder
os.chdir('/path/to/your/codebase')

# Regex pattern to match camel case file names
pattern = re.compile(r'.*/([a-z]+[A-Z]+.*)\.go$')

# Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
    for file in files:
        # Check if the file is a Go file with camel case name
        match = pattern.match(os.path.join(root, file))
        if match:
            old_name = match.group(1)
            new_name = re.sub(r'([a-z])([A-Z])', r'\1_\2', old_name).lower() + '.go'
            new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

            # Rename the file
            os.rename(os.path.join(root, file), new_path)
            print(f"Renamed {os.path.join(root, file)} to {new_path}")

ListOfCode.Content:
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import re
import subprocess

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    result = ""
    for i, char in enumerate(name):
        if char.isupper() and (i == 0 or (i > 0 and name[i-1].islower())):
            result += char.lower()
        elif char.isupper() and i > 0:
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                old_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                new_name = camel_to_snake(file[:-3]) + '.go'
                new_path = os.path.join(root, new_name)

                # Rename the file using 'git mv'
                git_mv(old_path, new_path)
                print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

                # Update go:generate statements in the file
                update_generate_statements(new_path)
                print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def rename_file(old_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    base_name = os.path.basename(old_path)
    new_name = None

    if base_name.endswith("Test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("Test.go")]
        new_name = "test_" + camel_to_snake(prefix) + ".go"
    elif base_name.endswith("_test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("_test.go")]
        new_name = camel_to_snake(prefix) + "_test.go"
    else:
        new_name = camel_to_snake(base_name)

    new_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(old_path), new_name)
    git_mv(old_path, new_path)
    print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

def camel_to_snake(name):
    """Converts a camel case string to snake case."""
    name = name.replace("nDC", "ndc")

    result = ""
    prev_char = ""
    for char in name:
        if char.isupper() and prev_char.islower():
            result += "_" + char.lower()
        else:
            result += char.lower()
        prev_char = char
    return result

def git_mv(old_path, new_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv'."""
    subprocess.run(['git', 'mv', old_path, new_path])

def rename_file(old_path):
    """Renames a file using 'git mv' and updates go:generate statements."""
    base_name = os.path.basename(old_path)
    new_name = None

    if base_name.endswith("Test.go"):
        prefix = base_name[:-len("Test.go")]
        new_name = "test_" + camel_to_snake(prefix) + ".go"
    else:
        new_name = camel_to_snake(base_name)

    new_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(old_path), new_name)
    git_mv(old_path, new_path)
    print(f"Renamed {old_path} to {new_path}")

    update_generate_statements(new_path)
    print(f"Updated go:generate statements in {new_path}")

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements with mockgen command
        pattern = r'//go:generate\s+mockgen\s+.*-destination\s+(\S+)\s*'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                old_path = match
                new_path = camel_to_snake(match)
                updated_content = content.replace(old_path, new_path)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

def main():
    # Change directory to your codebase root folder
    os.chdir(os.path.join(os.environ['HOME'], 'src/temporalio/temporal'))

    # Loop through each file in the directory and its subdirectories
    for root, dirs, files in os.walk('.'):
        for file in files:
            if file.endswith('.go'):
                file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                rename_file(file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

def update_generate_statements(file_path):
    """Updates the go:generate statements in a Go source code file."""
    with open(file_path, 'r+') as file:
        content = file.read()

        # Match go:generate statements
        pattern = r'(?m)^//go:generate\s+(.*)$'
        matches = re.findall(pattern, content)

        if matches:
            for match in matches:
                generate_line = match
                updated_line = generate_line

                # Find Go source code file names on the line
                file_names = re.findall(r'\b(\w+\.go)\b', generate_line)
                if file_names:
                    for old_name in file_names:
                        new_name = camel_to_snake(old_name)
                        updated_line = updated_line.replace(old_name, new_name)

                # Replace the go:generate line with the updated one
                updated_content = content.replace(generate_line, updated_line)
                file.seek(0)
                file.write(updated_content)
                file.truncate()

https://chat.openai.com/share/1270fc0a-f.Prompt: what is the difference between u"abc" and U"abc" in Python?
https://chat.openai.com/share/1270fc0a-f.Answer: In Python, the "u" and "U" prefixes before a string literal are used to indicate Unicode string literals. However, in Python 3, the "u" prefix is not necessary as all string literals are Unicode by default.In Python 2, the "u" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix is used to create a Unicode string literal that is treated as a raw string. A raw string treats backslashes as literal characters rather than escape characters. Here's an example to illustrate the difference:[CODE_BLOCK_0]However, in Python 3, all string literals are Unicode by default, and the "U" prefix is no longer recognized. You can simply use a regular string literal to represent Unicode strings:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In summary, the "u" prefix was used in Python 2 to indicate a Unicode string literal, while the "U" prefix was used to indicate a raw Unicode string literal. In Python 3, the "u" prefix is no longer necessary, and all string literals are Unicode by default.

# Python 2
u_string = u"abc"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"abc"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc
print(U_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = u"\n"  # Unicode string
U_string = U"\n"  # Raw Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)
print(U_string)  # Output: \n (literal backslash followed by 'n')

# Python 3
u_string = "abc"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: abc

# Backslash is treated as an escape character
u_string = "\n"  # Unicode string

print(u_string)  # Output: (newline character)

handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内でファイルの変更を監視する際に、イベントハンドラーが2回呼び出されることが原因です。これは、fs.watchメソッドが変更イベント(change)が発生した場合に複数回呼び出されることがあるためです。この問題を解決するには、handleWatchFileChangesメソッド内で最初の変更イベントが発生した時点でイベントハンドラーを一時的に無効化し、2回目以降の呼び出しを無視する必要があります。以下は修正例です：[CODE_BLOCK_0]上記の修正では、最初の変更イベントが発生した後、1秒間の間は監視フラグが無効化されます。その間に発生する変更イベントは無視されます。1秒後に監視フラグが再度有効化されるため、その後の変更イベントが再び処理されるようになります。この修正により、1回のファイル変更に対して1回のコンソールログと1回のリロードが行われるはずです。必要に応じて、無視する時間間隔を調整してください。

In github actions, I have this conditional:
```
 if [[ '${{ contains(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name, 'deploy:') }}' == 'true' ]]; then
...
```
which checks if any label on the pull request contains a label of the form `deploy: <env>`, where `<env>` can be any environment name, such as `qa` or `demo` (eg: `deploy: qa`).
Within the if block, I now need to determine what the environment name is. How can I do that?
https://chat.openai.com/share/71506eb6-0.Answer: To determine the environment name from a label like deploy: <env>, you'll need to extract <env> from the label name. Here's one way to accomplish this in GitHub Actions:Iterate over each label on the PR.For each label, check if it starts with deploy:.If it does, extract the environment name.Here's a sample workflow that demonstrates this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Few things to note:This uses the jq command-line JSON processor to manipulate the JSON output. GitHub runners come with jq preinstalled.echo "ENV_NAME=$env_name" >> $GITHUB_ENV is a way to set an environment variable that can be accessed in subsequent steps of the same job.The ${label#deploy: } syntax is a shell parameter expansion that removes the prefix deploy: from the $label, thus giving you just the environment name.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Extract Environment from PR Label

on:
  pull_request:
    types: [labeled]

jobs:
  extract-env:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Check for deploy label and extract environment
        run: |
          # Initialize env as empty
          env_name=""

          # Convert JSON labels to newline-separated list
          labels_list=$(echo '${{ toJSON(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name) }}' | jq -r '.[]')

          for label in $labels_list; do
            # Check if label starts with 'deploy:'
            if [[ $label == deploy:* ]]; then
              env_name=${label#deploy: }
              echo "Found deploy label for environment: $env_name"
              echo "ENV_NAME=$env_name" >> $GITHUB_ENV
              break
            fi
          done
          
          if [ -z "$env_name" ]; then
            echo "No deploy label found."
          fi

      - name: Use environment name
        run: |
          if [ -n "$ENV_NAME" ]; then
            echo "Deploying to environment: $ENV_NAME"
            # Place your deployment steps or logic here
          fi

# 入力文:
Next.jsのプロジェクトにおいてファイルシステムルーティング内のリンクに対してリンクを実装する場合はnext/linkのLinkコンポーネントを使用すると思いますが、Next.jsのプロジェクトとは関係のない外部のURLを使用してリンクを実装する場合もLinkコンポーネントを使用していいでしょうか？

# 出力文:
https://chat.openai.com/share/4a9bc421-3.Answer: Next.jsの<Link>コンポーネントは、HTMLの<a>要素を拡張し、プリフェッチングとクライアントサイドのナビゲーションを提供するReactコンポーネントです。これはNext.jsのルート間を移動する主要な方法です【7†source】。しかし、Next.jsのドキュメントや一部の開発者の意見では、外部のURLへのリンクを作成する場合は、通常は<Link>コンポーネントを使用しない方が良いとされています。その代わりに、通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用することが推奨されています【8†source】【15†source】【16†source】。しかし、Next.jsの<Link>コンポーネント内で外部リンクを作成したい場合は、passHrefという属性を使用することができます。この属性はデフォルトでfalseに設定されていますが、trueに設定することで、<Link>コンポーネントがhrefプロパティをその子要素に渡すことを強制します【14†source】。以下に、通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用する例と、passHref属性を使用する例を示します：[CODE_BLOCK_0]また、外部リンクと内部リンクを切り替えるためのカスタムコンポーネントを作成することも可能です。以下にその例を示します：[CODE_BLOCK_1]このように、<Link>コンポーネントは内部のリンクに対して使用されるべきですが、特定の状況下では外部のリンクに対しても使用可能です。ただし、外部のURLへのリンクには通常のHTMLの<a>タグを使用することが推奨されています。参照ソース：Components: <Link> | Next.js (nextjs.org) https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/linkjavascript - External link is not working in Next.js when you want to use Link component - Stack Overflow (stackoverflow.com) https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63558320/external-link-is-not-working-in-next-js-when-you-want-to-use-link-component

https://chat.openai.com/share/a6c84ecd-b.Prompt: I don't want to get the info as I already have it. I just want to find out if a string is a twitch loginname or StreamElements Account ID based on it's format
https://chat.openai.com/share/a6c84ecd-b.Answer: To determine if a string is a Twitch login name or a StreamElements account ID based on its format, you can use regular expressions. Regular expressions are a powerful tool for pattern matching and can help identify specific patterns within strings.Here's an example of how you can use regular expressions to differentiate between Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the regular expression patterns twitch_pattern and streamelements_pattern are used to define the expected formats for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, respectively. The re.match() function is used to check if the input string matches the patterns. If a match is found, it returns the corresponding identification ("Twitch login name" or "StreamElements Account ID"). If no match is found, it returns "Unknown".You can adjust the regular expressions to match the specific format requirements for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs, if necessary.

ListOfCode.Content:
import re

def identify_string(string):
    # Regular expression patterns for Twitch login names and StreamElements account IDs
    twitch_pattern = r"^[A-Za-z0-9_]{4,25}$"
    streamelements_pattern = r"^[a-fA-F0-9]{24}$"

    if re.match(twitch_pattern, string):
        return "Twitch login name"
    elif re.match(streamelements_pattern, string):
        return "StreamElements Account ID"
    else:
        return "Unknown"

# Example usage
string1 = "mytwitchusername123"
string2 = "5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3"
string3 = "invalid_string"

print(identify_string(string1))  # Output: Twitch login name
print(identify_string(string2))  # Output: StreamElements Account ID
print(identify_string(string3))  # Output: Unknown

The following regular expression can be used to match the ULID (Universally Unique Lexicographically Sortable Identifier) format:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Explanation:^ asserts the start of the string.[0-9A-HJKMNP-TV-Z] matches any character in the range 0-9, A-H, J-K, M-N, P-T, or V-Z.{26} specifies that the preceding character class should occur exactly 26 times (the length of a ULID).$ asserts the end of the string.Note that ULIDs are case-sensitive and use a modified base32 encoding, excluding the characters I, L, O, and Q to avoid confusion with numerals.

https://chat.openai.com/share/dc4b8dd7-f.Prompt: What do you mean by "you'd need to adjust headers accordingly"
https://chat.openai.com/share/dc4b8dd7-f.Answer: WAV files follow the RIFF (Resource Interchange File Format) structure. The header of a WAV file contains metadata about the file, such as its format, number of channels, sample rate, byte rate, block align, bits per sample, and more.When WAV files are concatenated naively (just putting one after the other), you end up with the headers of the second and subsequent files in the middle of the resulting file. This is usually not what you want and can lead to issues when trying to play the file. In essence, the resulting file won't be a valid WAV file.To concatenate WAV files properly and end up with a valid, playable WAV file, you would need to:Strip the headers from the second and subsequent files.Adjust the header of the first file to reflect the combined length and (possibly) other metadata changes.Concatenate the raw audio data.If you're considering concatenating WAV files to form a continuous audio stream, here's a rough idea:Read the header from the first WAV file and extract the necessary metadata. This includes the size field, which you'll need to adjust.For each subsequent WAV file, skip its header and only read the audio data.Update the size fields in the header of the first file to account for the total size of the concatenated audio data.Write out the adjusted header from the first file followed by the audio data from all files.There are libraries and tools designed to handle WAV and other audio formats that can assist with this, such as pydub:[CODE_BLOCK_0]With pydub, the WAV headers are handled automatically when you load, concatenate, and export audio.

ListOfCode.Content:
from pydub import AudioSegment

# Load the first WAV file
combined = AudioSegment.from_wav("file1.wav")

# Concatenate other WAV files
other_files = ["file2.wav", "file3.wav"]  # Add as many as needed
for file in other_files:
    sound = AudioSegment.from_wav(file)
    combined += sound

# Export the combined audio
combined.export("combined.wav", format="wav")

https://chat.openai.com/share/dc4b8dd7-f.Prompt: Does this need to be done for mp3 files?
https://chat.openai.com/share/dc4b8dd7-f.Answer: MP3 files have a different structure than WAV files, but they also have their own set of headers and metadata. MP3 files use frames to store audio data, and each frame has its own header. When you concatenate MP3 files, you're essentially stacking these frames together. Unlike WAV files, simple concatenation of MP3 files often results in a playable file. This is because many players will simply play through each frame they encounter in an MP3 file, even if they come from different original files.However, there are some considerations:ID3 Tags: Many MP3 files start or end with ID3 tags, which hold metadata about the song (like artist, album, and genre). If you simply concatenate MP3 files, the ID3 tags from the second and subsequent songs might appear in the middle of the resulting file. This doesn't usually disrupt playback, but the resulting file will have inaccurate or redundant metadata.Bitrate consistency: If you're concatenating MP3s with different bitrates or encoding settings, the result might not play smoothly on all players. It's generally a good idea to ensure all MP3 files have the same bitrate and encoding settings.VBR (Variable Bit Rate) MP3s: If your MP3s use variable bit rates, the resulting concatenated file might not report duration correctly on some players. This is because VBR files often use an additional header (like Xing or VBRI) to store seek information, and this header would only be accurate for the first file.Gapless Playback: If you aim for perfect, gapless playback, simple concatenation might introduce small gaps or clicks between songs.If you're looking to concatenate MP3 files and want to handle these potential issues:For simple use-cases, many command-line tools, like ffmpeg, can be used to concatenate MP3 files while handling the aforementioned issues.[CODE_BLOCK_0]If you need more control or are working within a Python environment, pydub (which was mentioned earlier for WAV files) can also handle MP3s. You'd need to have the lame encoder to work with MP3s in pydub.The bottom line is that while simple concatenation often works for MP3 files, for a cleaner and more reliable result, it's a good idea to use dedicated tools or libraries that understand the MP3 format's intricacies.

ListOfCode.Content: ffmpeg -i "concat:file1.mp3|file2.mp3|file3.mp3" -acodec copy output.mp3

https://chat.openai.com/share/8a774ccf-d.Prompt:
What SQL is generated by Django for this queryset:
`Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last()`
https://chat.openai.com/share/8a774ccf-d.Answer: The Django queryset Question.objects.filter(quest=quest).last() retrieves the last (most recent) Question object that matches the given filter condition quest=quest. The generated SQL query for this queryset would look something like:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Here, "yourapp_question" should be replaced with the actual database table name for the Question model in your Django application, and 'desired_quest_value' should be replaced with the specific value you are filtering on.The query first filters the rows based on the quest column value, orders the results in descending order by the primary key column (id is a common primary key field name in Django), and then limits the result to just one row using the LIMIT 1 clause to retrieve the last matching Question object.

ListOfCode.Content:
SELECT *
FROM "yourapp_question"
WHERE "yourapp_question"."quest" = 'desired_quest_value'
ORDER BY "yourapp_question"."id" DESC
LIMIT 1;

https://chat.openai.com/share/972081f0-c.Prompt: is it possible to write a validation code in php which checks whether uploaded file size is under 1MB?
https://chat.openai.com/share/972081f0-c.Answer: Yes, it is possible to write a validation code in PHP to check whether an uploaded file size is under 1MB. Here's an example code snippet that demonstrates how you can achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this code, we first check if the form was submitted using the $_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"] variable. If it was a POST request, we access the uploaded file information using $_FILES["fileUpload"].We check if there are no errors during the file upload using the UPLOAD_ERR_OK constant. Then, we retrieve the file size using $file["size"]. We compare the file size to the maximum allowed size (1MB in this case) and display an appropriate message based on the result.Remember to adjust the maxSize variable according to your specific requirements if you want to allow a different maximum file size.Note: It's important to consider additional security measures when dealing with file uploads, such as validating file types, using file extensions, and preventing code execution from uploaded files.

ListOfCode.Content:
<?php
// Assuming you have a file upload form with the input name "fileUpload"

if ($_SERVER["REQUEST_METHOD"] == "POST") {
    $file = $_FILES["fileUpload"];

    // Check if there are no errors during file upload
    if ($file["error"] == UPLOAD_ERR_OK) {
        // Check the file size
        $fileSize = $file["size"]; // Size in bytes

        $maxSize = 1048576; // 1MB in bytes

        if ($fileSize <= $maxSize) {
            // File size is within the limit
            // Proceed with further processing or storing the file
            echo "File uploaded successfully.";
        } else {
            // File size exceeds the limit
            echo "File size should be under 1MB.";
        }
    } else {
        // Error occurred during file upload
        echo "Error uploading file.";
    }
}
?>

The 'fileUpload' field is defined as required and file type, and the max rule is used to limit the file size to 1024 kilobytes (1MB).If the validation fails, the code redirects back with the validation errors. Otherwise, you can proceed with further processing or storing the file. Access the uploaded file using $request->file('fileUpload') and perform the necessary operations.Remember to adjust the 'max' rule parameter according to your specific requirements if you want to allow a different maximum file size.It's recommended to follow Laravel's file upload security best practices as well, such as validating file types and using storage mechanisms to store the uploaded files securely.

ListOfCode.Content:
<?php
use Illuminate\Http\Request;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Validator;

// Assuming you have a file upload form with the input name "fileUpload"

public function uploadFile(Request $request)
{
    $validator = Validator::make($request->all(), [
        'fileUpload' => 'required|file|max:1024', // Max file size in kilobytes (1MB = 1024KB)
    ]);

    if ($validator->fails()) {
        // Validation failed
        return redirect()->back()->withErrors($validator);
    }

    // File size is within the limit
    // Proceed with further processing or storing the file
    // Access the uploaded file using $request->file('fileUpload')
    // e.g., $request->file('fileUpload')->store('path-to-store');

    return redirect()->back()->with('success', 'File uploaded successfully.');
}
?>

https://chat.openai.com/share/522cd0a9-1.Prompt: Write a script to upload an image to AWS S3 using the Elixir programming language
https://chat.openai.com/share/522cd0a9-1.Answer: Sure! Here's an example script to upload an image to AWS S3 using the Elixir programming language and the ex_aws library:[CODE_BLOCK_0]To use this script, you'll need to add the ex_aws dependency to your mix.exs file:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Then, run mix deps.get to fetch the dependencies.To upload an image, you can call the upload_image/3 function from the S3Uploader module, providing the bucket name, file path, and key as arguments:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Make sure to replace "your-bucket-name" with the actual name of your S3 bucket, "/path/to/image.jpg" with the path to the image file you want to upload, and "images/my-image.jpg" with the desired key under which the image will be stored in the S3 bucket.Note: Ensure that you have set up the necessary AWS credentials in your environment variables or other appropriate credential provider methods supported by ex_aws.

ListOfCode.Content:
defmodule S3Uploader do
  @moduledoc """
  A module for uploading images to AWS S3.
  """

  def upload_image(bucket, file_path, key) do
    {:ok, credentials} = ExAws.Credentials.from_env()

    # Configure ExAws with your AWS credentials
    ExAws.Config.put_credential_provider(:default, credentials)

    # Configure ExAws with your desired AWS region
    ExAws.Config.put_region(:default, "us-east-1")  # Replace with your desired region

    {:ok, binary} = File.read(file_path)

    {:ok, _} = ExAws.S3.upload(bucket, key, binary)

    IO.puts "Image uploaded successfully!"
  end
end

defp deps do
  [
    {:ex_aws, "~> 2.1"},
    {:hackney, "~> 1.15"},
    {:poison, "~> 4.0"}

https://chat.openai.com/share/633e2b6f-6.Answer: The getPointNearCenter method is trying to find a point near the center of a set of polygons. It does this by first finding the bounding rectangle of all the points of the polygons. Then it computes the center of that rectangle (which may not be on any of the polygons). Finally, it generates a point based on a gaussian distribution with the center as the mean and a third of the width and height as the standard deviation.However, the Gaussian (or normal) distribution is not restricted to a specific range - it can theoretically generate any number from negative infinity to positive infinity. While the numbers it generates are more likely to be close to the mean, there's still a chance they could be beyond the minimum and maximum coordinates of the polygons, which means the point it generates might not land on the polygons at all.To fix this, you might want to generate a point that is definitely within one of the polygons. You could do this by picking a random polygon and then a random point within that polygon. For simplicity, let's assume that these polygons are triangles. Then you can generate a random point within a triangle using barycentric coordinates:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This function first chooses a random triangle from the set of triangles. Then it generates two random numbers between 0 and 1. These numbers are used as barycentric coordinates to generate a point that is guaranteed to be within the chosen triangle.

If leftToRight is true, it loops through the grid left to right, top to bottom (more natural way). If it is false, it loops through the grid top to bottom, left to right.However, these calculations are based on the size of inventory (28 slots in a 4x7 grid), which means c and r should always be within their respective bounds. That's why the condition if (c >= 0 && c < 4 && r >= 0 && r < 7) is always true.This condition seems redundant and can be removed. The issue here is that there is a return statement inside the inner loop, so the method returns on the first iteration, no matter what. This means it will always return the first point of the first triangle within the range.If you want to get all the points in the triangles within a specified range, you need to store them in a collection like a List, and return that instead of just a single point. However, if you just want to get the first point that meets a certain condition, then the condition should be specified in an if statement within the inner loop.Without knowing the exact purpose of this function, it's hard to suggest a precise fix, but here's a sample adjustment assuming you want to collect all points in the triangles within the specified range:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This version of the function will return a list of points from all triangles in the specified range. If there are no triangles within the range, it will return an empty list. It's generally better to return an empty list rather than null to avoid NullPointerExceptions.

Looking at this usage, the getPointInRange method is supposed to return a random point from the triangles in a given range. Since you're using the first and second halves of the triangle list separately in the getPoint method, the getPointInRange method is expected to pick a point randomly from the specified range, not just return the first point.Here's how you might modify the getPointInRange method:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This version of getPointInRange will collect all points from the triangles within the specified range and then pick a random point from those. If there are no points in the range, it will return null. This behavior matches the usage in the getPoint method, which checks for null after calling getPointInRange.

https://chat.openai.com/share/0b7b9fec-3.Prompt: in python, how get the result of exec()
https://chat.openai.com/share/0b7b9fec-3.Answer: In Python, the exec() function is used to execute dynamically created program, which is either a string or object code. If it is a string, the string is parsed as a suite of Python statements which is then executed. If it is an object code, it is simply executed.The exec() function does not return any value, hence you can't directly get a result from it like you would from a function that returns a value.However, the exec() function optionally takes a globals and locals parameter (both must be dictionaries), which it uses for global and local variables during execution. If you want to get a result from exec, you can pass a dictionary for locals, execute an assignment statement, and then retrieve the result from the locals dictionary.Here is a small example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the code to be executed is a string that declares two variables a and b and a third variable result which is the sum of a and b. After executing this code with exec, the locals_ dictionary is updated with the values of a, b, and result, and you can get the value of result by looking it up in the dictionary.Please note, using exec() can potentially make your code vulnerable to code injection if you are executing code that comes from an untrusted source or includes user inputs. It is generally best to avoid using exec() if possible.

ListOfCode.Content:
code = """
a = 1
b = 2
result = a + b
"""

locals_ = {}
exec(code, {}, locals_)
print(locals_['result'])  # Output: 3

https://chat.openai.com/share/954082b4-d.Prompt: what's the difference between openapi oneOf vs anyOf ?
https://chat.openai.com/share/954082b4-d.Answer: In OpenAPI, oneOf and anyOf are JSON Schema keywords used to define the validation rules for request or response payloads. They are used to specify alternative schemas that a given value must conform to.Here's the difference between oneOf and anyOf:oneOf: It specifies that a value must match exactly one of the provided schemas. In other words, the value must adhere to the constraints of exactly one of the defined schemas. If a value matches multiple schemas, it would be considered invalid. It enforces a mutually exclusive choice.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above example, the value must either be a string with a maximum length of 5 or a number greater than or equal to 10.anyOf: It specifies that a value must match at least one of the provided schemas. The value can conform to any of the defined schemas, allowing for multiple valid options. If a value matches multiple schemas, it is considered valid.Example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In the above example, the value can be a string with a maximum length of 5 or a number greater than or equal to 10. It can satisfy either condition.To summarize, oneOf enforces a single, exclusive choice among the provided schemas, while anyOf allows for multiple valid options by matching any of the provided schemas.

ListOfCode.Content:
oneOf:
  - type: string
    maxLength: 5
  - type: number
    minimum: 10

anyOf:
  - type: string
    maxLength: 5
  - type: number
    minimum: 10

https://chat.openai.com/share/a41f5514-8.Prompt: How can I implement a health check in Docker Compose for Keycloak 21?
https://chat.openai.com/share/a41f5514-8.Answer: To implement a health check for Keycloak 21 in Docker Compose, you can use the healthcheck configuration option available in Docker Compose version 2.1 or higher. The healthcheck option allows you to define a command or script that Docker will periodically run to check the health of a container.Here's an example of how you can implement a health check for Keycloak 21 in Docker Compose:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example:We define a service named keycloak.We specify the Keycloak Docker image (jboss/keycloak:11.0.0 in this case).We map the container's port 8080 to the host's port 8080 to access Keycloak.We define the healthcheck configuration block for the keycloak service.In the test field, we specify the command ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/master"]. This command uses curl to make an HTTP request to Keycloak's /auth/realms/master endpoint. The -f flag ensures that curl returns a non-zero exit code if the request fails.We set the interval to 30s, indicating that Docker should run the health check every 30 seconds.We set the timeout to 10s, specifying the maximum time Docker waits for the health check command to complete.We set the retries to 5, which means Docker will attempt the health check command up to 5 times before considering the container unhealthy.With this configuration, Docker will periodically run the curl command to check the health of the Keycloak container. If the command fails (returns a non-zero exit code) or exceeds the specified timeout, Docker will consider the container unhealthy.

ListOfCode.Content:
version: '3.8'
services:
  keycloak:
    image: jboss/keycloak:11.0.0
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "curl", "-f", "http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/master"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

https://chat.openai.com/share/a41f5514-8.Answer: If curl is not installed in the Keycloak container, you can use alternative tools like wget or nc (netcat) to perform the health check. Here's an example of how you can modify the health check command using wget:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, we use the wget command with the --quiet option to suppress output, --tries=1 to attempt a single connection, and --spider to check the URL without downloading the content. If wget encounters an error or fails to establish a connection, it will return a non-zero exit code, indicating an unhealthy state.Alternatively, you can use nc (netcat) to perform a basic TCP connection check. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]In this case, we use the nc command with the -z option to scan for open ports, -w2 to specify a 2-second timeout, and localhost and 8080 as the host and port to check. If the connection fails or times out, nc will return a non-zero exit code, indicating an unhealthy state.Choose the approach that works best for your use case based on the tools available in your Keycloak container.

ListOfCode.Content:
version: '3.8'
services:
  keycloak:
    image: jboss/keycloak:11.0.0
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "wget --quiet --tries=1 --spider http://localhost:8080/auth/realms/master"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

version: '3.8'
services:
  keycloak:
    image: jboss/keycloak:11.0.0
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD", "nc", "-z", "-w2", "localhost", "8080"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

https://chat.openai.com/share/5a28b049-8.Answer: When a time is ambiguous due to a Daylight Saving Time (DST) transition, it is important to disambiguate it to obtain a correct Unix timestamp. In the case of the 'Europe/Amsterdam' timezone, there is a DST transition on the last Sunday of March at 2:00 AM, when the clock is set forward by one hour, and another transition on the last Sunday of October at 3:00 AM, when the clock is set back by one hour. This means that any time between 2:00 AM and 3:00 AM on the day of the transition occurs twice: once during DST and once during standard time.To disambiguate such a time, you can use the tm_isdst field of the tm structure, which indicates whether the time is in DST or standard time. This field can be set to -1 to indicate that the mktime() function should determine whether DST is in effect for the specified time. If the tm_isdst field is set to 0 or 1, the mktime() function will use the specified DST flag, regardless of whether DST is actually in effect.Here's an updated version of the code that disambiguates an ambiguous time by checking whether DST is in effect for that time:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated code, we set the tm_isdst field to -1 before calling mktime(), which tells the function to determine the DST flag for the specified time. After calling mktime(), the tm_isdst field is updated with the DST flag that was used to convert the time to a Unix timestamp. This flag can be used to determine whether the time is in DST or standard time.

In this implementation, we use the NVS to store the previous timestamp and DST flag between measurements. We first load the previous timestamp and DST flag from the NVS and use them to determine the DST flag for the current timestamp if necessary. Note that this implementation assumes that the device's clock is synchronized with the local time zone. If this is not the case, you may need to adjust the timestamp accordingly before converting it to a Unix timestamp.

https://chat.openai.com/share/c18aff35-9.Prompt: I'm trying to set up the github action for running npm test but it complains that there's no package-lock.json
https://chat.openai.com/share/c18aff35-9.Answer: GitHub Actions is a tool that enables you to automate, customize, and execute your software development workflows right in your GitHub repository.You're seeing an error message because your repository doesn't have a package-lock.json file. The package-lock.json file is automatically generated when npm install is run and it describes the exact tree that was generated such that subsequent installs are able to generate identical trees, regardless of intermediate dependency updates.Here are a few ways to resolve this:Add a package-lock.json file:Run npm install in your project's root directory locally. This will create a package-lock.json file if there isn't one already.Commit and push the package-lock.json file to your GitHub repository.Use npm ci instead of npm install:If you're using npm install in your GitHub Actions workflow, you may want to switch to npm ci. npm ci is a more reliable and faster alternative for continuous integration environments. However, it requires a package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to be present.Here's a basic example of a GitHub Actions workflow file for running npm test:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Remember that you still need to commit and push your package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to your GitHub repository to use npm ci.Disable the package-lock.json check:If you don't want to use a package-lock.json file, you can disable the check in your .npmrc file by adding the following line:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Please note that by doing this, you lose the benefits of having a package-lock.json file. Also, make sure to update your GitHub Actions workflow to use npm install instead of npm ci, because npm ci requires a package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json file to work.

ListOfCode.Content:
name: Node.js CI

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    strategy:
      matrix:
        node-version: [14.x]

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v2
      with:
        node-version: ${{ matrix.node-version }}
    - run: npm ci
    - run: npm test
package-lock=false

https://chat.openai.com/share/bec0bb09-4.Answer: To create a custom JSON marshaler, we need to implement the MarshalJSON method on our type.Here is how you can achieve this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above code, FunctionDefine has two fields that both represent "parameters". The MarshalJSON method first checks if ParametersRaw is non-nil. If it is, it uses ParametersRaw as the source for the "parameters" field in the JSON output. If ParametersRaw is nil, it marshals Parameters instead, and uses the result as the source for the "parameters" field.This is achieved by creating an anonymous struct with the same structure as FunctionDefine, but with a new Parameters field. This new field is of type json.RawMessage, which can hold a raw slice of bytes that is included as-is when marshaling to JSON.In the call to json.Marshal, the code passes a pointer to a new instance of this anonymous struct. It sets the Alias field to a new Alias (alias of FunctionDefine) instance pointing to fd, and sets the Parameters field to the parameters variable prepared earlier. As a result, the fields of fd (except ParametersRaw and Parameters) are included as-is in the JSON output, and the "parameters" field in the JSON output is sourced from either ParametersRaw or Parameters as appropriate.Note: the Alias is used to prevent infinite recursion in the MarshalJSON method.

https://chat.openai.com/share/7ebfba32-d.Prompt:
Let's say I have a table called `responses` with a text field called `comment` that can contain strings like these:

"I got a lot of help from @4154 and @64 this week."
"@4154 thanks a million!!! Also @12"

How would I do a query using Ruby on Rails to return all of the numbers that exist in the table into an array? For example `[4154, 64, 4154, 12]`
https://chat.openai.com/share/7ebfba32-d.Answer: You could do this in several steps in Ruby on Rails using ActiveRecord (the database interface in Rails) and regular expressions.First, you'll need to pull all the comments from your database. Then you'll extract the user ID's using a regex match, and finally, you'll flatten the array (since the match method returns an array of matches).Here's an example on how you might do it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This will give you an array of integers like [4154, 64, 4154, 12].Keep in mind this is a simple example and might not cover more complex use cases. For example, it assumes that the "@" character is always immediately followed by the user ID without any space. It also assumes that every string of numbers is a user ID, even if it isn't preceded by the "@" character. You would need a more complex regex if your actual use case doesn't meet these assumptions.

ListOfCode.Content:
# Get all comments from the responses table
comments = Response.pluck(:comment)

# Define regex pattern for @ followed by digits
pattern = /@(\d+)/

# Extract all user ID's into an array
user_ids = comments.map { |comment| comment.scan(pattern) }.flatten

# Convert all elements to integer (as they will be strings after the regex)
user_ids = user_ids.map(&:to_i)

results = ActiveRecord::Base.connection.execute("
  SELECT
    REGEXP_MATCHES(comment, '@(\d+)', 'g')

https://chat.openai.com/share/49417c2c-0.Prompt: i know there is a way to use a specific instance of S3 of SQS using boto3.client or boto3.resource by passing in a endpoint_url to these functions, but is there a way to do it globally using a set_endpoint_url function or something similar?
https://chat.openai.com/share/49417c2c-0.Answer: Yes, you can set the endpoint URL globally for the AWS SDK using the boto3.setup_default_session() function. This function allows you to configure default settings for the AWS SDK, including the endpoint URL for services like Amazon S3 and Amazon SQS.Here's an example of how you can set the endpoint URL globally using boto3.setup_default_session():[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the example above, the boto3.setup_default_session() function is used to configure the default session for the AWS SDK. The region_name parameter is also set, but it's optional and can be omitted if not needed.After setting up the default session, any subsequent calls to boto3.client() or boto3.resource() will use the configured endpoint URL automatically. You don't need to pass the endpoint_url parameter explicitly every time.Note that the global configuration set by boto3.setup_default_session() will be applied to all client and resource objects created using boto3.client() and boto3.resource() without explicitly specifying an endpoint URL. If you want to use different endpoint URLs for different services or scenarios, you can still pass the endpoint_url parameter to the individual client/resource creation functions, and it will override the global configuration for that specific client/resource instance.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Set the endpoint URL globally
endpoint_url = 'https://your-custom-endpoint.amazonaws.com'
boto3.setup_default_session(region_name='us-east-1', endpoint_url=endpoint_url)

# Now all subsequent client/resource creation will use the configured endpoint URL
s3_client = boto3.client('s3')
sqs_resource = boto3.resource('sqs')

# Use the S3 client and SQS resource with the custom endpoint URL
s3_client.list_buckets()
sqs_resource.create_queue(QueueName='my-queue')

Adjust the endpoint URL if you're using a different LocalStack endpoint configuration.Please note that LocalStack may have limitations and may not fully emulate all SQS features or behaviors, so it's advisable to consult the LocalStack documentation for any specific considerations or limitations when using it with boto3 and SQS.

ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3

# Configure the endpoint URL for LocalStack SQS
endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4566'

# Create the SQS client
sqs_client = boto3.client('sqs', endpoint_url=endpoint_url)

# Use the SQS client with LocalStack
queue_name = 'my-local-queue'

# Create an SQS queue
response = sqs_client.create_queue(QueueName=queue_name)
queue_url = response['QueueUrl']
print(f"Created queue with URL: {queue_url}")

# Send a message to the SQS queue
message_body = 'Hello, LocalStack SQS!'
response = sqs_client.send_message(QueueUrl=queue_url, MessageBody=message_body)
print(f"Sent message with ID: {response['MessageId']}")

# Receive messages from the SQS queue
response = sqs_client.receive_message(QueueUrl=queue_url, MaxNumberOfMessages=1)
messages = response.get('Messages', [])
for message in messages:
    print(f"Received message with ID: {message['MessageId']}, Body: {message['Body']}")

# Delete the SQS queue
sqs_client.delete_queue(QueueUrl=queue_url)
print(f"Deleted queue: {queue_url}")

import boto3
from botocore.client import Config

# Configure the endpoint URLs for different services
s3_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4572'
sqs_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4576'

Here's an updated example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this updated example, the event listeners are registered using the event name 'service-created.s3' for S3 and 'service-created.sqs' for SQS. ListOfCode.Content:
import boto3
from botocore.client import Config

# Configure the endpoint URLs for different services
s3_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4572'
sqs_endpoint_url = 'http://localhost:4576'

# Create custom session objects with different endpoint URLs
s3_session = boto3.session.Session()
sqs_session = boto3.session.Session()

# Register event listeners for S3 to set the endpoint URL
s3_session.client('s3').meta.events.register(
    'service-created.s3',
    lambda event, **kwargs: event.add_to_service(
        'endpoint_url', s3_endpoint_url
    )
)

# Register event listeners for SQS to set the endpoint URL
sqs_session.client('sqs').meta.events.register(
    'service-created.sqs',
    lambda event, **kwargs: event.add_to_service(
        'endpoint_url', sqs_endpoint_url
    )
)

# Set the custom sessions as default session factories
boto3.setup_default_session(
    region_name='us-east-1', 
    botocore_session=s3_session,
    session=boto3.DEFAULT_SESSION
)

boto3.setup_default_session(
    region_name='us-east-1', 
    botocore_session=sqs_session,
    session=boto3.DEFAULT_SESSION
)

# Now all subsequent client/resource creation will use the registered sessions
s3_client = boto3.client('s3')
sqs_client = boto3.client('sqs')

# Use the S3 client and SQS client with the custom endpoint URLs
s3_client.list_buckets()
sqs_client.list_queues()

https://chat.openai.com/share/75cd8eae-6.Answer: This error is occurring because the document object is also a part of the web API and not available in a Node.js environment. Jest suggests using the "jsdom" test environment when you are testing code that relies on DOM APIs.In the "jsdom" environment, Jest creates a document object which behaves as if you're in a browser-like environment. This way, you can do things like query the DOM with document.querySelector() or modify the DOM with element.textContent.To use the "jsdom" environment, you can specify it in your jest.config.js file:[CODE_BLOCK_0]If your Jest configuration is not in jest.config.js but in package.json, you can add the "testEnvironment" option there:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Now Jest will use "jsdom" as the environment when running your tests, and you should have access to the document object.However, according to the code you shared earlier, you are already setting up JSDOM manually in your test file, so document should be defined. If the setup isn't working as expected, switching to Jest's built-in "jsdom" environment as shown above might be a more reliable option.

https://chat.openai.com/share/75cd8eae-6.Answer: The error message you're seeing, "ReferenceError: TextEncoder is not defined", comes from a missing global object TextEncoder that's expected in the web environment but is not available in the Node.js environment where Jest runs.From Node.js 11.0.0, TextEncoder and TextDecoder are globally available. However, for older versions of Node.js or for environments where these constructors are not natively available, you can install them from npm:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then, in your Jest setup file or at the top of your test file, you can import and globally define TextEncoder and TextDecoder:[CODE_BLOCK_1]However, it's good to note that if your Node.js version is outdated, it's advisable to update to a newer version where TextEncoder and TextDecoder are globally available.You might also consider migrating to an LTS version (Long Term Support) of Node.js, which as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, is version 14.x. The LTS versions of Node.js tend to be more stable and are preferred for production applications.

We just need to make sure we're cleaning up properly in our beforeEach setup, specifically by calling localStorage.clear() and resetting document.body.innerHTML.

You're correct, my apologies for that oversight. We've modified the game.js file to use the Game class and encapsulate the related functions within that class. Consequently, we should update the onclick handlers in your index.html file to reflect this change.In the previous game.js implementation, startPlaying(), switchUser(), and backfillResults() were global functions, which is why they could be invoked directly from inline onclick handlers in your HTML. However, these methods are now encapsulated within the Game object.So, to resolve this, you need to create a new Game object in your HTML file and use it to call these methods. Here's how to modify your index.html:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Please replace #startPlayingButton, #switchUserButton, and #backfillResultsButton with the correct IDs of the buttons in your HTML. This inline script creates a new Game instance and then uses that instance to add event listeners to the appropriate buttons. ListOfCode.Content:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Banzuke Surfing Game</title>
    <script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.5.1/jquery.min.js"></script>
</head>
<body>
    <!-- The rest of your HTML content -->

    <!-- Link to the external JavaScript file -->
    <script src="game.js"></script>
    <script>
        const game = new Game();

        document.querySelector("#startPlayingButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.startPlaying());
        document.querySelector("#switchUserButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.switchUser());
        document.querySelector("#backfillResultsButton").addEventListener('click', () => game.backfillResults());
    </script>
</body>
</html>

https://chat.openai.com/share/75cd8eae-6.Prompt: why am i back to inlining javascript
https://chat.openai.com/share/75cd8eae-6.Answer: I apologize for the confusion. To avoid inlining JavaScript code in the HTML file and keep the separation of concerns intact, you can create a new initialization function in the game.js file that sets up the event listeners. Then, you can call this function in the HTML file.Here is how to do this:Modify game.js to export a function that sets up the event listeners:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Call initGame function in index.html:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This way, the JavaScript code related to the Game class remains in the game.js file, and the HTML file is only responsible for calling the initialization function, preserving the separation of concerns between HTML and JavaScript.

https://chat.openai.com/share/75cd8eae-6.Answer: This error is happening because the export statement appears after your inline script, and as per ES6 module syntax, import and export statements may only appear at the top level of your module (i.e., not nested inside a script, function, or block).Since you're trying to work in both a browser environment (which doesn't natively support ES6 modules) and a Node.js environment (where you're using Jest and want to import your Game class), one solution could be to switch to using the Universal Module Definition (UMD) pattern.UMD allows a JavaScript module to work in both browser and server environments and also supports AMD and CommonJS module styles.Here is how you could modify game.js to use UMD:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Then in your Jest test:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Now the module should be correctly loaded in both browser and server environments.

# Fury

Fury is a powerful and flexible command-line utility for managing file operations. The crate is built with Rust and is designed to make tasks like copying, moving, and deleting files quick and easy.

## Features

- File Copy: Copies a file from one location to another.
- File Move: Moves a file from one location to another.
- File Delete: Deletes a file from a location.

## Usage

You can use the `fury` command line tool as follows:

### Copy a File

```sh
$ fury copy /path/to/source/file /path/to/destination
$ fury move /path/to/source/file /path/to/destination
$ fury delete /path/to/file
$ git clone https://github.com/username/fury.git
$ cd fury
$ cargo build --release

Please replace `username` with your actual GitHub username. Make sure to create a `CONTRIBUTING.md` and `LICENSE` file, if you've mentioned them in the README. The `LICENSE` file should contain the details of the MIT license (or whichever license you wish to use), and the `CONTRIBUTING.md` should contain guidelines for potential contributors.
